5019f766c33f08a7595efff8f0402b0a:
Paraguay opened its embassy in Jerusalem on Monday, becoming the second country to follow the United States in making the politically sensitive move from Tel Aviv.
The United States relocated its embassy to Jerusalem a week ago, drawing Palestinian anger, and was followed by Guatemala on Wednesday.
Israel claims the holy site to be its undivided capital, but Palestinians seek East Jerusalem as the capital of any future state.
The international consensus is that the status of the city should be negotiated through bilateral negotiations.
Most countries keep their embassies in Tel Aviv and have rejected the idea of relocating their diplomatic missions away from the city unilaterally.
The other countries that have expressed an interest in moving their missions to Jerusalem include Honduras, Czech Republic and Romania.
At the US embassy inauguration last week, Mr Trump said the move had been a long time coming.
But just miles away in Gaza, tens of thousands of Palestinian protesters rallied against the move and conditions in the enclave.
Israeli forces shot 60 people dead, including several children, sparking international outrage.
c4f278aaac80f73823c1c82e0b3c64c1:
Paraguay opened its embassy to Israel in Jerusalem on Monday, May 21, 2018.
Paraguay is the third country to open an embassy in Jerusalem, following the United States and Guatemala.
The United States opened its embassy in Jerusalem on May 14, 2018.
Widespread protests broke out in West Bank cities and Gaza after the United States opened its embassy in Jerusalem.
More than 60 Palestinians were killed and over 3,000 wounded in clashes with the Israeli Defense Forces.
Israel seized East Jerusalem in the 1967 Mideast War.
Israel annexed East Jerusalem and declared it as part of its "eternal and indivisible capital."
Palestinians consider East Jerusalem as the capital of their future state.
The peace talks between Palestine and Israel have been stalled since April 2014.
9b5b12084e7dc602cfda4c03c0e478da:
Paraguay opened its embassy in Jerusalem, becoming the third country to do so.
The embassy is located in the Malha Technological Park, the same building where Guatemala inaugurated its embassy last week.
Paraguayan President Horacio Cartes and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu attended the opening ceremony.
Netanyahu praised Paraguay as a "true friend" of Israel and recalled its support during the Holocaust and the partition vote in the UN in 1947.
Cartes said the embassy opening "expresses the sincere friendship and brave solidarity" between the two countries.
Netanyahu indicated that cooperation with Paraguay would be "greater in several areas including agriculture, security and technology."
Paraguay's embassy opening comes one week after the United States opened its embassy in Jerusalem and two days after Guatemala opened its embassy there.
Other countries, including the Czech Republic, Romania, and Honduras, have expressed desire to move their embassies to Jerusalem.
05c3a5e2315b686b01e7ea81668d3686:
Paraguay opened its new embassy in Jerusalem on Monday, becoming the third country to transfer its diplomatic mission in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.
Romania, the Czech Republic and Honduras are considering doing the same.
President Donald Trump’s announcement on Jerusalem in December was welcomed by the Israeli government but infuriated the Palestinians.
The U.S. Embassy move added fuel to the weekly Palestinian protests in Gaza demanding the right of return to Israel and the lifting of a decade-old naval blockade.
The protests culminated last Monday, when Israeli forces killed nearly 60 Palestinians in clashes along the border.
The heavy death toll triggered a diplomatic backlash, with Turkey expelling Israel’s ambassador and consul general and several European countries summoning the Israeli ambassadors to their foreign ministries for questioning.
The U.S. Embassy move has also sparked others to rally in support of Israel.
Israel’s Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said at the ceremony that he was there to “salute” a great friend.
The opening of the embassy was “a great day for Israel, a great day for Paraguay, a great day for our friendship,” Netanyahu said.
4d61451adc80a9d8a3ecee85d53b7272:
The White House praised Paraguay for relocating its embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.
Paraguayan President Horacio Cartes and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu attended the May 21 inauguration.
The United States became the first country to move its embassy to Jerusalem on May 14, 2018.
The United States hopes to welcome "many more of our friends and allies in Jerusalem, the capital of Israel."
The Palestinian Authority condemned Paraguay's move as "illegal, illegitimate, an act of aggression against the Palestinian people and their rights, a violation of relevant United Nations resolutions and international law, and submission to American and Israeli dictates and bribes."
ac1adc8865646e164db2aebfc7e0ffae:
Guatemala moved its embassy to Jerusalem from Tel Aviv on Wednesday, two days after the US made the same move.
Guatemalan President Jimmy Morales, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Israeli President Reuven Rivlin and several heads of state from both countries were present at the momentous ceremony.
Guatemala supported the creation of the State of Israel in 1948 and was the second country to recognize it, after the US.
The embassy is located in Jerusalem's Malha Technological Park.
Guatemala was the first country in the world to open an embassy in Jerusalem in 1956, but moved it to Tel Aviv in 1980.
Paraguay and Honduras will also move their embassies to Jerusalem.
The Czech Republic and Romania have expressed interest in moving their embassies to Jerusalem.
Russia recognized "west Jerusalem" as the Israeli capital in April 2017.
4af0c6ab01e72c785d25762bcae6409e:
United States casino magnate Sheldon Adelson provided Guatemala’s official delegation a Boeing 767 to travel to Israel for the relocation of its embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.
Guatemalan foreign minister Sandra Jovel said Adelson provided the plane last week to carry government officials and guests, including religious leaders.
Manfredo Marroquin, director of civil society organization Citizen Action, said President Jimmy Morales’s administration violated Guatemalan law, which forbids accepting such gifts.
Guatemala’s human rights prosecutor, Jordan Rodas, also said the arrangement with Adelson was concerning.
Morales’s decision to move Guatemala’s embassy just two days after the US did the same was seen by many as an attempt to curry favor with US President Donald Trump.
fd411979d5ee2111f772f0aa95e7c440:
An Alexandria military court issued preliminary death sentences against 36 people convicted of involvement in deadly bombings on two Egyptian churches in Alexandria and Tanta in April 2017.
The case involves 48 defendants, 31 of whom are in custody and 17 are fugitives.
The court has referred the case to the country's Grand Mufti for his non-binding opinion on the death sentence as per Egyptian law.
The verdict is subject to appeal.
The defendants were convicted of a number of terrorist attacks against civilians and policemen in 2016 and 2017.
In April 2017, suicide bombers attacked St George's Church in Tanta and St Mark's Cathedral in Alexandria on Palm Sunday, killing 46 people and injuring dozens.
The defendants were also charged with participating in a January 2017 attack on a security checkpoint in Egypt’s New Valley governorate near the Western Desert, killing eight policemen.
ac1824df8ffb507219a0310f9b796252:
Egypt’s Court of Cassation overturned death sentences and jail terms and ordered a retrial for defendants previously convicted in the “Waraq terrorist cell” case.
The court ordered the retrial after reviewing appeals filed by eight of the defendants, who had been sentenced to verdicts ranging from five-year prison terms, life imprisonment and death sentences.
The defendants will be retried in a different criminal court district.
A Giza criminal court sentenced two of the defendants to death, two to life imprisonment, and four to five-year terms in 2021.
The defendants were convicted of joining an outlawed group, killing a policeman and a civilian, and possessing weaponry in Waraq district, northern Giza in February 2016.
7fd1877fafef5052ad8d02d7b7f62cd2:
An Egyptian court has sentenced 11 people to death by hanging for involvement in a deadly gunfire over car washing.
The sentences were issued by the Cairo Criminal Court on Tuesday against the 11 defendants convicted of murder, show of force and terrorizing the public.
The convicts include six brothers.
The verdict can be appealed.
Two people were killed and five injured in the gunbattle that dates back to April last year in the working-class area of Old Cairo.
The fight started with a fracas after one of the convicts blocked the traffic in a local street by washing cars as a source of a livelihood.
The quarrel developed into a pitched fight between relatives of both sides, who used firearms.
The two dead were pedestrians, who were caught in the crossfire.
In recent months, Egyptian authorities have toughened penalties against using water in car washing and spraying streets in an attempt to conserve water.
Offenders can face a fine of 20,000 Egyptian pounds (Dh4,246) and a jail term of up to six months.
Egypt is worried that a disputed dam being constructed by Ethiopia on the Nile will cut Egypt’s share of the river’s waters.
Last week, Egypt, Ethiopia and Sudan—three riparian countries—failed to clinch a deal on the hydroelectric Renaissance Dam building.
5d254d31006102752f8a5a8999efde77:
Egypt’s military criminal court referred 36 members of the ISIS terrorist group to the Grand Mufti after they were sentenced to death for attacks against churches in the country.
The defendants are suspected of involvement in bombings that hit three Coptic churches, killing at least 70 people.
Egypt requires that courts refer cases to the Grand Mufti for consideration of the death penalty ahead of a final verdict.
The court will issue a final verdict on May 15.
Eleven of the 36 are being tried in absentia.
Some of the suspects held leadership positions in ISIS and formed cells to carry out the church attacks.
Some of the defendants are also accused of carrying out an attack on a checkpoint in Egypt’s Western Desert that killed at least eight policemen in 2017.
07e413514b29fa7539c2b0cf4f449880:
Egypt's former anti-corruption chief Hisham Geneina will face military trial for saying a presidential candidate he supported had documents damning to state officials.
Geneina had been a top campaign aide to Sami Anan, whom the military also detained after he announced he would stand in last month's presidential election against incumbent Abdel Fattah al-Sisi.
Geneina had said the documents Anan allegedly possessed "revolve around political events and crises Egyptian society has passed through" since the January 2011 uprising.
Moataz Wadnan, the journalist who conducted the interview, has also been arrested.
a4b2c2f275a2eb3e4fa9dc06ef6e4c57:
Egypt’s Court of Cassation will hand down its unchallenged ruling on the retrial of former Muslim Brotherhood Supreme Guide Mohamed Badie over charges of inciting violence in the “Rabaa operation room case” on Saturday.
Badie, along with 17 other defendants, have appealed against court verdicts ranging from life imprisonment to five years in jail.
Badie was the eighth leader of the banned Muslim Brotherhood (MB) organization.
Badie was arrested on August 19, 2013 as part of a nation-wide crackdown on Brotherhood leaders in the wake of increasing violence and protests after two Brotherhood sit-ins were forcefully dispersed on August 14, 2013.
Badie is still being tried in 11 known cases, mainly over charges of “inciting violence.”
Badie and former Islamist President Mohamed Morsi, with 20 co-defendants, are being retried over charges of “spying” for Palestine’s Gaza-based Hamas movement.
Badie is being charged with “staging an armed gathering in Rabaa Square, illegally possessing and handling weapons, blocking driveways, and deliberately vandalizing public property, along with other counts relating to murdering policemen and citizens” in the Rabaa sit-in dispersal case.
Badie and 27 co-defendants are being tried in the case of breaking into Egyptian prisons, known as the break-in of the eastern border in 2011.
Badie and 12 other defendants are being retried by the Cairo Criminal Court over charges of inciting murder against peaceful demonstrators outside the MB Guidance Bureau in Moqattam, Cairo in 2013.
Badie and 13 other Brotherhood members are being retried in the “al-Bahr al-Azam case”, in which they are charged with “inciting clashes” in al-Bahr al-Azam district, Giza, causing death of five people.
Badie and 13 co-defendants were charged with killing 10 and attempting to murder 20 others in the clashes outside Istiqama Mosque in Giza.
Badie is being charged over inciting violence in the clashes in El Idwa, Minya governorate, following the Rabaa sit-in dispersal on August 14, 2013.
A total of 105 defendants, including Badie, are being tried in the “Ismailia incidents case”, in which they are charged with inciting violence, and killing and injuring people in clashes between pro-Muslim Brotherhood supporters and security forces outside the Brotherhood office in Ismailia in July 2014.
Badie and Brotherhood members Mohamed El-Beltagy and Safwat Hegazy were sentenced to 10 years in prison by a military court in December 2015 over charges of inciting riots in Suez.
Badie and 92 other defendants are being retried over charges of “setting fire” to state institutions in Beni Suef following the dispersal of the Rabaa sit-in.
4e58bbe732460a1f5d37abd971a65274:
An Egyptian court upheld the life sentence against Mohamed Badie, head of the outlawed Muslim Brotherhood group, over violence charges.
The Court of Cassation, Egypt's top court that gives final verdicts, upheld the verdicts of life and rigorous imprisonment against Badie and 17 other Brotherhood members for their involvement in the armed sit-in and attempted murder.
The defendants are accused of scheming a terrorist plot that aimed at vandalizing vital government facilities and places of worship.
They are also charged with directing the Brotherhood members to defy the government and to spread chaos in the country.
Most Brotherhood leaders, including ousted former President Mohamed Morsi and Badie, are currently in custody.
Morsi himself is currently serving a 20-year prison sentence on charges of inciting clashes between his supporters and opponents outside a presidential palace in Cairo in late 2012 that left 10 people killed.
17aeb26cfacc0a743eb0a44ed6ea3ef6:
An Egyptian court upheld a life sentence against Mohamed Badie, the leader of the banned Muslim Brotherhood, over 2013 violence.
The court of cassation, Egypt’s top court, rejected an appeal by Badie and others against verdicts issued against them last May in the case known as “the Rabaa Operations Room” trial.
The case relates to a sit-in in Rabaa to support ousted President Mohamed Mursi who hailed from the Muslim Brotherhood.
The sit-in was forcibly dispersed by security forces, leaving hundreds dead.
Badie and two others were sentenced to life imprisonment in the case, 15 others were sentenced to five years while 21 people were acquitted.
The defendants were charged with leading an illegally founded organization, plotting to stir chaos and publishing false news among other crimes.
Authorities outlawed the Brotherhood after Mursi was ousted, and arrested thousands of its supporters.
Decisions made by the court of cassation are final and cannot be appealed.
Saturday’s life sentence is the third against Badie.
61a1f6aa53d64f009f5bbaa4617c861a:
Egypt's former anti-corruption chief Hisham Genena has been referred to a military court for trial on charges of spreading false news harmful to the military establishment.
Genena ran alongside former military chief-of-staff Sami Anan as a member of his short-lived presidential campaign before Anan was detained in January.
Genena was arrested and put under investigation by the military prosecutor in February over comments he had allegedly made in an interview with the HuffPost Arabi news website.
Genena's lawyer, Ali Taha, gave no further details about the charges he faced.
Genena is due in court on April 16.
Family members say Genena is depressed and in poor physical condition.
bfc47e2590ad759337b5c52c36c6cbc9:
An Egyptian court upheld a life sentence against Mohamed Badie, the leader of the banned Muslim Brotherhood, over 2013 violence.
The court of cassation, Egypt's top court, rejected an appeal by Badie and others against verdicts issued against them last May in the case known as "the Rabaa Operations Room" trial.
The case relates to a sit-in in Rabaa to support ousted President Mohamed Morsi who hailed from the Muslim Brotherhood.
The sit-in, which began after the army ousted Morsi, was forcibly dispersed by security forces, leaving hundreds dead.
Badie and two others were sentenced to life imprisonment in the case, 15 others were sentenced to five years while 21 people were acquitted.
The defendants were charged with leading an illegally founded organisation, plotting to stir chaos and publishing false news among other crimes.
Authorities outlawed the Brotherhood after Morsi was ousted and arrested thousands of its supporters.
They also dissolved its Freedom and Justice Party, which Morsi led.
Decisions made by the court of cassation are final and cannot be appealed.
Saturday's life sentence is the third against Badie.
dac8938b9d85dda727b809c90a5c61fc:
Egypt's Court of Cassation upheld death sentences against four defendants convicted of terror-related charges in the 2015 "Ousim terrorist cell case.”
The court also upheld jail sentences ranging between 15 years to life for 29 defendants in the same case.
The defendants were convicted of forming and operating a terrorist cell with the aim of undermining the constitution, targeting public and private property, threatening law enforcement officers, as well as a failed assassination attempt on a judge in March 2015.
The defendants were also accused of orchestrating and carrying out a number of terrorist attacks in Giza governorate.
The Sunday Court of Cassation verdict is not subject to appeal.
2b535bcb6f9494e1f3598c1c62c9b6a7:
Egyptian top court removed 31 members and supporters of the Muslim Brotherhood group from the terrorist list over a case related to the deadly protests in 2014.
The 2014 protests erupted after then army chief Abdel-Fattah al-Sisi announced running for president a year after he ousted former Islamist President Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood.
Cairo Criminal Court sentenced 17 defendants to 25 years in jail, nine to 15 years, four to 10 years and two to seven years while acquitting 15 of the charges of committing acts of violence.
Egypt has been facing a wave of terror attacks that have killed hundreds of policemen and soldiers, as well as civilians since Morsi's ouster in early July 2013.
A Sinai-based militant group affiliated with the regional terror group Islamic State has claimed responsibility for most of the attacks.
The Egyptian forces have killed hundreds of terrorists and arrested thousands of suspects during the country's anti-terror war declared by Sisi following Morsi's ouster.
3cf21cf239edf26699020cf0c9de6cf9:
An Egyptian court sentenced four Colombian nationals to 10 years in prison each for their involvement in five burglaries in New Cairo.
The court acquitted the defendants for six other thefts.
The defendants formed a gang specialised in burglarising homes in the wealthy 5th Settlement district in new Cairo.
The defendants confessed to breaking into five villas.
Christian Camillo, Jorman Fenanand, Michael Humberto and Christian Esteban were arrested by a special police unit at an apartment in downtown Cairo's Abdeen district on 8 April.
Police found gold and diamond jewelry weighing about 2kg, as well as cash in several currencies upon searching the apartment.
8125fcf1f4ac80abfa4598a0bb064cef:
Cairo’s Court of Cassation upheld a primary ruling to list 46 defendants as terrorists over the killing of former Attorney General Hisham Barakat.
Egypt’s top court of appeals rejected a challenge filed by the 46 defendants to cancel their terror designation.
Cairo Criminal Court sentenced 28 defendants to death, 15 defendants to life imprisonment, eight defendants to 15 years in prison and 15 defendants to 10 years in prison for being involved in the assassination of Barakat.
The defendants are facing other charges that include being associated with Palestinian militant group Hamas, aiming to foment instability in the country and illegally possessing firearms.
Barakat was assassinated on June 29, 2015, when a car bomb detonated in his car outside his home in Cairo’s Heliopolis neighborhood.
148ac755c3afdb70c47d0401c7fec0e6:
A military court will pronounce the verdict on Hisham Geneina, former head of the Central Auditing Organization, on April 24, over his controversial statements to HuffPost Arabi.
Geneina was arrested on February 13 following his statement about Sami Anan, the now arrested former presidential candidate, where Geneina said that Anan possesses documents against the country's current leadership, which he kept outside Egypt.
Geneina's lawyers, including Farid al Deeb, expressed objection to their client’s trial by a military court, claiming that Geneina’s case does not fall under the jurisdiction of the military court.
Military spokesperson Tamer el-Refai said that the Egyptian army will investigate the statements, saying that they drive a wedge between the Egyptian army and the citizens amid a war against terrorism.
Anan Junior accused Geneina of slander and spreading false information on the behalf of his father.
422880eb5e1dbfac1fb4816d873d92bc:
An Egyptian military court sentenced former anti-corruption chief Hisham Geneina to five years in jail for making statements against the army.
Geneina claimed that a presidential candidate had secret documents allegedly damaging to the army.
Geneina was detained in February for "spreading news that harms the armed forces" following an interview he gave to Huffpost Arabi.
The journalist who conducted the interview, Moataz Wadnan, was also arrested.
Geneina was sacked by President Abdul Fattah al-Sisi as head of the Central Auditing Authority in 2016 after he was accused of exaggerating the cost of corruption in Egypt.
bd27802918e0cde22a2962e430b364b9:
An Algerian court has sentenced a Liberian national to death for "spying for Israel."
Six other individuals of different sub-Saharan nationalities were sentenced to 10 years in prison with fines of up to 20 million Algerian dinars (26,000 U.S. dollars).
The defendants were charged with spying, conspiracy to seriously undermine Algeria's security, and glorifying terrorism.
The defendants pleaded not guilty, claiming that they entered Algeria in order to reach Europe.
The seven people were arrested in January 2016 by security services in downtown Ghardaia amid a violent sectarian strife in the region.
31a1746faadd760cd2b5f0f03a0623f5:
Egypt’s Court of Cassation overruled a verdict to add 161 defendants on terror lists on charges of establishing a terrorist group affiliated with ISIS.
The Court of Cassation ordered that the decision be reviewed before the Criminal Court.
Seventy-eight defendants had filed appeals against the Cairo Criminal Court's decision to blacklist them.
The Public Prosecution had charged the accused with joining an illegal group, aimed at obstructing the constitution and laws and preventing state institutions from carrying out their duties.
The Court of Cassation set a hearing for July 10 to issue a verdict on the appeals submitted by 119 Muslim Brotherhood leaders and members against their blacklisting.
The defendants on terror lists include a number of Muslim Brotherhood Guidance Office members, most notably Mahmoud Ezzat, Mohammed Abdulrahman al-Morsi and Mahmoud Hussein.
6f7ed4126b1fe9452496a515b482e1bd:
Egypt's first democratically elected president Mohamed Morsi was in court on charges of "communication with Hamas".
The prosecution charged Morsi and a number of others with crimes including communicating with foreign organisations outside the country in order to commit terrorist acts in the country, disclosing defence secrets to a foreign state and those working for its interests, financing terrorism, military training to achieve the purposes of the Muslim Brotherhood, and committing acts that undermine the country's independence, unity and territorial integrity.
Morsi has been on trial in a number of cases since his ouster in a military coup in 2013.
Human rights groups have repeatedly lambasted the Egyptian government for its treatment of the former president and other political prisoners who they say are being held on trumped up charges.
7f4066439b8ffc2780510cf184ce8033:
Egypt's top court upheld the death penalty for six Muslim Brotherhood loyalists for attacking a police station in 2013.
The court reduced the execution verdicts against three defendants to 25-year imprisonment, upheld the 25-year jail for 59 defendants and acquitted 47 others.
The convicts stormed a police station in Minya's Matay town, stole weapons, killed a senior policeman, attempted to murder others, allowed detainees to escape and set fire to the police station.
The convicts were supporters of ousted Islamist President Mohamed Morsi and committed the acts of violence following the security dispersal of pro-Morsi sit-ins in 2013.
Morsi was removed by the army in 2013 in response to mass protests against his rule and his Muslim Brotherhood group.
Morsi is currently serving a 20-year prison sentence for inciting deadly clashes and a 25-year jail term for leaking classified documents.
Egypt has been facing a wave of terror attacks since Morsi's ouster, with a Sinai-based militant group affiliated with the Islamic State claiming responsibility for most of the attacks.
The Egyptian forces have killed hundreds of terrorists and arrested thousands of suspects during the country's anti-terror war.
6d097899d9f2a90d5cf905c67f0b9e4f:
A Cairo criminal court sentenced 13 policemen to between three and five years in prison for breaking an assembly law when they gathered to demand higher wages and better working conditions in 2015 and 2016.
The policemen were also convicted of detaining another police officer they claimed had mistreated a colleague in their home province of Sharqiya, in the Nile Delta.
The Cairo court of Cassation confirmed death sentences passed on six people, and life sentences on 59 others, accused of storming and setting fire to a police station in the southern province of Minya in 2013.
93672f22d4ff26f2d0fc417a0bfd2bb1:
Egypt’s prosecutor-general Nabil Sadek summoned five Cairo officials for questioning after heavy rainfall last week caused floods that damaged property in New Cairo.
The officials summoned are the deputy head of the New Urban Communities Authority (NUCA), the municipal head of New Cairo, chairman of the Great Cairo Sewage Company, and the chief legal officers at NUCA and the Holding Company for Water and Wastewater.
Residents of New Cairo took to social media to express their frustration at the perceived negligence by officials and emergency departments.
The public prosecutor also ordered the formation of a committee of urban development and engineering professors as well as members of the country’s main anti-corruption body to inspect drainage systems at the affected area.
The committee is tasked with identifying the reason behind the floodwater accumulation and the power outage, as well as estimate the amount of money spent on maintenance and take legal action if any wrongdoing is determined to have taken place.
de2e082e50e6b6ae60875ac6f86b5641:
Egypt's general prosecution referred 318 members of the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant – Sinai Province (ISIL-SP) to the military court on charges of planning terrorist attacks against military and police forces.
The list of defendants included the Egyptian national fugitive Tarek el Zomor, former chairman of Building and Development Party.
Tarek el Zomor is accused of funding the terrorist activities in Egypt following July 2013.
Tarek el Zomor was among terrorists who assassinated former Egyptian President Anwar Sadat during a military parade on October 6, 1981.
Tarek el Zomor is currently the Chairman of Al Jama’a Al-Islamiyya and the Building and Development Party.
f207df240d6af6fd60afe414b8e0c5fb:
Egypt's judicial authorities sentenced 11 members of the Muslim Brotherhood group, which Cairo considers a terrorist organization.
An Egyptian court accused 170 ISIS elements of photographing an air base and targeting vital installations in the case known as "filming the Belbeis airbase."
The court set the hearing on June 12 to issue the verdicts for 170 ISIS elements.
The indictment added that the terrorist elements have also received by illegal means one of the country’s defense secrets by taking photos, using a mobile phone, for Belbeis air base in preparation for targeting it.
Egypt’s security forces launched an all-out offensive against militants in February, deploying tens of thousands of troops and police backed by fighter-jets, helicopter gunships, navy vessels and tanks in Sinai and in the Western Desert.
Egypt has been battling ISIS elements for years, but the insurgency gathered steam and grew deadlier after the 2013 ouster by the military, then led by Sisi, of Mohammed Morsi.
bd79efa4a88e0cf702e847e575f3cbde:
An Egyptian criminal court has placed 169 members of the banned Muslim Brotherhood group on the country's terror list.
The defendants are facing charges of conspiring to infiltrate state institutions with the aim of overthrowing the regime by force and spreading chaos in the country.
The court’s decision is based on state security investigations, which revealed that the defendants attempted to revive the group's activities by recruiting new members to its armed wings, spread rumors and provided financial and logistical assistance to the Brotherhood.
Under the country’s anti-terrorism law, any person placed on the terror list is subject to a travel ban and having their assets frozen.
Egypt's terror list contains over 1,500 names, including top Brotherhood leaders.
97e8906e2b4c6afbb26f589f93305f6f:
Egyptian police detained Amal Fathy, a member of the banned April 6 youth movement, for posting a video criticizing the government's handling of sexual harassment and worsening living conditions.
Amnesty International condemned the arrest as a "new low in Egypt's crackdown on freedom of expression."
Fathy's husband, Mohamed Lotfy, a human rights lawyer, was detained with her but released three hours later.
Fathy is being held for 15 days for questioning on charges of incitement to overthrow the ruling system, publishing lies, and misusing social media.
Egyptian media criticized Fathy for using foul language in the video.
A security source said Fathy is accused of insulting the Egyptian state by posting a video containing swearing and defamation.
c92518d4cb92cf75032a246b935154d6:
A Cairo court in Egypt ordered 20 Muslim Brotherhood members to be placed on terrorist lists for the next five years.
The court based its decision on proof that the accused were terrorists because some of them were leaders of the Brotherhood.
The 20 terror suspects are charged with purchasing weapons and arms, and receiving funds through Brotherhood leaderships abroad.
The Cairo Criminal Court set August 4 as the date for the retrial of seven defendants in the so-called Tanta terror cell case.
The suspects are charged with forming a terror cell in the western city of Tanta for the purpose of attacking the army and police.
ae871afd6c35753322f195cc1eb1f4cc:
An Egyptian court acquitted two police officers of torturing to death a lawyer while in detention three years ago.
The ruling can be appealed.
The lawyer, Kareem Hamdi, was arrested on suspicion of belonging to the banned Muslim Brotherhood and involvement in its violence.
Hamdi died inside a police station in the northern Cairo district of Matariya.
Lawyers accused police of torturing Hamdi to death allegedly to extract confessions from him.
The country’s chief prosecutor ordered both officers from the National Security Agency to stand trial on charges of torturing the lawyer to death.
In December 2015, a court sentenced the two to five years in prison each.
In October 2016, the Court of Cassation, Egypt’s top appeals tribunal, revoked the verdict and ordered a retrial for both defendants.
Egyptian authorities have pursued a relentless crackdown on Islamists since 2013 when the military toppled president Mohammad Mursi of the Brotherhood following massive protests against his rule.
Rights groups have repeatedly accused the government of ignoring police’s purported violations.
Authorities have downplayed the alleged abuses as isolated acts, vowing to bring any wrongdoer to justice.
In recent years, several policemen have been handed down varying jail terms in separate torture cases in Egypt.
Police abuses were seen as a major catalyst for the 2011 revolt that forced long-time president Hosni Mubarak out of power.
73938bc24f092056c2482ada90539467:
An Egyptian court has acquitted two police officers of charges of torturing and murdering a prominent lawyer in 2015.
Egypt's prosecutor has referred some 278 terror suspects to a military court on charges of joining two breakaway Muslim Brotherhood factions.
The news of the overturned conviction comes amid controversy over a leaked video released last week that appears to show a child being executed at close range in Egypt's Sinai Peninsula by an army officer, dating back to 2015.
In February Amnesty International condemned the escalating "human rights crisis" in Egypt in its annual World Report, citing the country's endemic arbitrary arrests and detentions of hundreds, as well as the new legal restrictions imposed on NGOs and authorities turning a blind eye to torture.
In September, the Egyptian government pledged to take action against Human Rights Watch after it released a damning report on state torture.
President Abdel Fattah Al-Sisi told US officials in New York that human rights should not be judged from a Western perspective, arguing that Egypt had taken numerous measures to ensure the economic and social wellbeing of its citizens.
1a15724a5e5459a57464cf187d00d3bf:
An Ismailia criminal court issued preliminary death sentences to 13 defendants convicted of escaping El-Mostakbal prison in 2016.
The court has referred the case to the country's grand mufti for a non-binding opinion on the death sentences.
The defendants include members of Ansar Beit Al-Maqdis terrorist organisation, now known as Daesh Sinai.
A final sentence will be issued by the court on 12 July.
390d57fa0b462181b72fe1c4a6d26679:
Egypt's Prosecutor-General Nabil Sadek referred 278 defendants belonging to the Muslim Brotherhood group to military court for leading and joining the banned armed groups Hasm and Lewaa El-Thawra.

Egyptian military court sentenced Ismail Alexandrani, a prominent journalist and expert on extremist movements in the Sinai peninsula, to 10 years in prison.
Alexandrani was arrested in November 2015 and accused of publishing military secrets and belonging to the banned Muslim Brotherhood.
Alexandrani was also accused of spreading information that could harm national security outside the country in interviews with the media and in articles.
Alexandrani's lawyer said they will appeal the verdict.
Alexandrani had been in pretrial detention for two and a half years since his arrest in the Red Sea resort of Hurghada after he returned from a work trip in Berlin.

Alexandrani had been to Germany to deliver lectures on the political situation in Egypt.
Alexandrani was also known for his anti-regime writings and for criticising the military's role in politics.
Alexandrani was a contributor to publications including the French online magazine Orient XXI.
Co-defendant Walid Mohareb was also sentenced to 10 years in prison in the same trial.

Islamic scholar Tariq Ramadan has lost an appeal for early release ahead of his trial in France over rape allegations by four women.

A second woman, who is disabled, claims that Ramadan raped and beat her in a hotel in the southeastern city of Lyon in 2009.
The third accuser, a French Muslim woman who is using the pseudonym "Marie", came forward in early March and claims to have suffered multiple rapes in France, Brussels and London between 2013 and 2014.

Amnesty International has asked the Algerian authorities to release a blogger, Merzoug Touati, who faces the death penalty on “espionage charges.”
Touati interviewed an Israeli foreign ministry spokesperson in which he disputes accusations by the Algerian authorities that the Israeli authorities were involved in protests in Algeria.
Touati faces charges relating to a Facebook post and YouTube video that authorities claim encouraged civil unrest.
Touati has been in detention since January 2017.
Amnesty International has reviewed the court documents and found that there was no incitement to violence or advocacy of hatred in Touati's posts.
Amnesty International considers Merzoug Touati a prisoner of conscience held solely for expressing his peaceful opinions.
Heba Morayef, Middle East and North Africa regional director at Amnesty International, said that every day “Touati spends in prison ... is a further stain on Algeria’s human rights record.”

A court in the Algerian city of Béjaïa sentenced blogger Marzouk Touati to ten years in prison for communicating with Israel and inciting civil disobedience.
Touati was also fined 50,000 dinars ($430).
The Attorney General of the Béjaïa Judiciary Council had asked for a life sentence.
Touati posted a video on his website of a dialogue that he had with someone alleged to have been the official spokesman for the Israeli Foreign Ministry for Arab media.
Algerian security forces raided Touati's house and confiscated his computer, and concluded that he had relations with several people who had escaped from Algerian justice and were living in Arab countries like Morocco.
Touati also had relations with people from countries including Israel, where he was in contact with local activists.
One of the Israeli activists was called "Gabrielle Qatouf" and asked for information about the property of Jews in Algeria in exchange for money, which Touati refused to provide.
The Attorney General claimed that Touati asked the activists to present him with an Israeli official to deal with.
Someone identified as a colonel in the intelligence services and a spokesman for the Israeli Foreign Ministry for the Arab media then conducted a dialogue with him.
Touati is said to have provided him with information about races and ethnicities in Algeria, as well as his own CV and university certificates in order to travel to Israel.
465e0cd5ffa73ac62eb4f16c4329c172:
The Court of Cassation postponed the appeal of Muslim Brotherhood leader Hassan Malek and 55 other MB members for being included on the terror list until July 14.
The defendants were accused of hurting the Egyptian economy by smuggling foreign currencies and financially supporting terrorist groups.
Malek was arrested by security forces in 2015 and referred to the Emergency Court by the attorney general.
Malek was sentenced to seven years in prison in 2006 for being a leader in the Muslim Brotherhood, but was pardoned in 2011.
Malek's work has been versatile, but mainly revolved around manufacturing/selling conservative attire for women, as well as computers.

The ultra-Orthodox community would still enjoy various exemptions from the regular conscription law, such as its recruits only being obligated to join the army from the age of 24, and not 18 like the regular draft.

The ultra-Orthodox United Torah Judaism party has given an ultimatum that if a proposal dealing with the community’s conscription is not passed into law by June 22, the party will leave the government.
The Defense Ministry hopes to create a “durable, realistic and relevant arrangement that will meet the needs of the IDF as an equal and national army, stand up to the Supreme Court ruling cancelling [the previous law] and receive the necessary wide approval in order to become law.”
The ultra-Orthodox parties have submitted two parallel bills on the military draft, including a quasi-constitutional Basic Law that would enshrine long-term Torah study as a recognized form of official service to the state in lieu of military service.

The ultra-Orthodox parties have submitted two parallel bills on the military draft. The first, a quasi-constitutional Basic Law, would enshrine long-term Torah study as a recognized form of national service in lieu of military service.

Cabinet ministers authorized a bill to criminalize filming certain Israeli military activities, including clashes between IDF soldiers and Palestinians.
The bill would subject anyone caught filming or publishing footage of military activities with the purpose of harming “the soldiers’ morale” to up to five years behind bars.
Proponents said they will compromise on the bill’s much-criticized restrictions so that the prohibition on filming soldiers will only fall on those actively clashing with troops and attempting to obstruct their activities.
Filming a soldier while obstructing him from carrying out his duties will carry a maximum sentence of up to three years in prison.
More serious circumstances, such as publishing such footage with the intention of “harming state security,” can carry a punishment of up to 10 years in prison.
Attorney General Avichai Mandelblit said he would not be able to defend the law if it advanced in its current form.

B’Tselem NGO slammed the bill as “idiotic” and said that visual footage of life under occupation will continue.
Daniel Sokatch, CEO of the dovish New Israel Fund, criticized the proposed measure and said that video footage of police and military activity has become an important tool for human rights groups and the media.

Gafni’s office later backtracked somewhat, saying “the leading rabbis are the ones who will decide on the enlistment law – and as long as they have not had their input there is no formal decision on the issue.”
Several experts have noted that the targets are not particularly high and the financial penalties for not meeting them not especially severe.

Defense Minister Avigdor Liberman joined opposition leaders in rejecting calls to grant ultra-Orthodox community vast exemptions from the military draft.

Yesh Atid party head Yair Lapid called on the government to pass the bill without any changes to the Defense Ministry recommendations.
Zionist Union leader Avi Gabbay said the party will vote against any legislation enshrining into law exemptions to mandatory military service for ultra-Orthodox students.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the proposed bill must be passed into law by the Knesset within two weeks.
A rabbinic advisory board to four of the six members of the UTJ party called on its lawmakers to leave the coalition if the bill was passed.
Jewish Home leader and Education Minister Naftali Bennett dismissed talk of a coalition crisis over the legislation.

United Torah Judaism head Yaakov Litzman said if a ultra-Orthodox-backed proposal dealing with the community’s conscription is not passed into law by July 22, the party will leave the government.
The ultra-Orthodox parties have submitted two parallel bills on the military draft, one would enshrine long-term Torah study as a recognized form of national service in lieu of military service, and the other would force the Defense Ministry to grant deferrals to yeshiva students.

Israel’s first President Chaim Weizmann foresaw the ensuing existential battle over the unholy alliance of religion and politics.

The heads of both Haredi parties, Shas’s Aryeh Deri and UTJ’s Yaakov Litzman, reiterated their opposition to the bill.
Defense Minister Avigdor Liberman of the secularist Yisrael Beytenu party expressed support for the bill.

United Torah Judaism’s Litzman said earlier this month that if an ultra-Orthodox-backed proposal dealing with the community’s conscription is not passed into law by July 22, when the Knesset summer recess begins, the party will leave the government, likely spelling its untimely end.
The ultra-Orthodox parties have submitted two parallel bills on the military draft.

MK Yoel Hasson from the opposition Zionist Union faction seeks to pressure the Yesh Atid party into opposing legislation addressing ultra-Orthodox military enlistment.

In 2015, a state comptroller report found that expenditures at the prime minister’s residence had been excessive and improper.
Sara Netanyahu was indicted last week for charging some NIS 359,000 ($100,000) in gourmet meals to the state’s expense between 2010 and 2013.
Mandelblit is also reportedly considering bringing bribery charges against Benjamin Netanyahu in so-called Case 1000, or the gifts case.

Deputy Health Minister Yaakov Litzman threatened to bring down the coalition if the bill becomes law.

Lapid argued that the legislation is close to a similar bill his party had pushed for in the past.
The current bill does not call for criminal sanctions against students who dodge the draft, only economic penalties against the institutions where they study.
The current bill also has a lower quota for the number of ultra-Orthodox who will be drafted each year.
The issue of ultra-Orthodox enlistment has been a contentious one in Israel for decades.
In September 2017, the High Court of Justice struck down a previous law exempting ultra-Orthodox men from military service.
The court suspended its decision for a year to allow for a new arrangement to be put in place.
88da8220b9b0a4d68a3a4ceabb309970:
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu emphasized that the new IDF draft bill is the coalition's top priority.

However, he said the new law will not require government and public ministries to include Arabic in their publications, as they currently have to do.
Arab citizens of Israel are Palestinians who stayed put during the 1948 war.
They formed Israel's largest minority and often complain about lack of job opportunities, racism, and discrimination in all fields of life, including access to health, education, transportation, and municipal services.

Deputy Health Minister Yaakov Litzman threatened to resign from the government unless the High Court of Justice postpones the implementation of a bill regulating mandatory military service for members of Israel’s Haredi community.

Attorney General Avichai Mendelblit warned Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of possible international implications if the Nation-State Bill is passed in its current form.
Deputy Attorney General Ran Nizri also said that the passage of the bill would have international ramifications.
The legislation would prioritize Jewish values over democratic ones and allow the establishment of communities that are segregated by religion or nationality.
Likud is looking into the possibility of changing the wording of one of the controversial clauses in the bill, clause 7b, which allows for the establishment of Jewish-only communities.
The Yisrael Beiteinu party also suggested two alternative wordings Tuesday for the controversial clause.

The export of goods from Iran's Kermanshah province to Iraqi Kurdistan has increased by 51 percent over eight months of this Iranian year (started on March 21, 2018).
The trade turnover between Iran and Iraq is increasing despite the US sanctions.
Iran is interested in sending its products to Syria via Iraq because now this route passes through Turkey and requires additional time and extra costs.
Iran hopes that transport and visa issues will be solved within the next few months.
Kermanshah province has a 371-kilometer-border with Iraq.

Iran exported $2.222 billion worth of products to Afghanistan during the first eight months of the current Iranian year, a 26 percent increase compared to the same period last year.
Iran imported $7.6 million worth of goods from Afghanistan during the same period, a 44 percent decrease compared to the same period last year.
Iran mainly imports sesame, agricultural products and marble from Afghanistan.
The increase in Iranian exports to Afghanistan is attributed to the efforts of Iranian Trade and Development Organization representatives and Iranian trade attachés in Afghanistan.
Afghan businessmen have been investing in Iran's carpet weaving, food industry and hotel industry in recent years.

Iran's exports to Azerbaijan increased by 50% to $301 million during the eight months of the current Iranian calendar year (started on March 21).
Iran's exports to Azerbaijan account for 1% of the country's total exports.
Iraq is the largest export market for Iranian goods, followed by China and the United Arab Emirates.
Azerbaijan ranks 12th on the list of Iran's target markets.
5eb231adceefb1767a02ae7b6e82eb44:
Iran exported $986 million worth of commodities to Iraq through Mehran Border Crossing during the past nine months through Dec. 21.
The figure indicates a 9% increase compared with the corresponding period of last year, when the value of exports to Iraq through the border stood at around $907 million.
An average of 600 commercial vehicles pass through the Mehran Border Crossing every day.
The exports through Mehran reach $10 million in some days.
Last year, products worth $1.2 billion were exported to Iraq through Mehran border.
The goods exported during the nine-month period mainly included agricultural, plastic and polyethylene commodities, steel products, car parts, and construction materials, such as stone, tiles and ceramics, as well electrical and mechanical machinery.
